root.sourcetext: In the street, I saw a cat and a dog. The dog was barking furiously. It is perhaps symptomatic that examples of the anaphoric use of definite noun phrases in the literature tend to contain antecedents which are parts of a conjoined noun phrase: at least in natural speech, pronouns tend to be preferred to full noun phrases as straightforward anaphors in most contexts, and we need a structure such as a conjoined NP for there to be two equally possible antecedents, in which case a definite NP is motivated.
I met the author of Syntactic Structures.
I have to fix my computer: there is some problem with the hard disk.
Last year, I saw a film by Ingmar Bergman. I would like to see that/the film again.
The northern hairy-nosed wombat is an endangered species.
John studies the species Felis catus.
John studies cats, because he is not allowed to use humans for his experiments.
There are not many wombats left.
The wombat is rare these days.
There are lions in Kenya and Tanzania.
The lion is represented in both Kenya and Tanzania.
A sudden dizziness came upon me.
The Americans have visited the moon.
The Swedes have visited the moon.
father prog.3.sg drink.GER def beer exact hour ‘Father is drinking beer right now.’ (Pier Marco Bertinetto, pers.comm.)
